facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 1 of 1950 by special leave from an order of the High Court of Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Appeal  Criminal Appeal No. 1 of 1950  by special leave from an order of the High Court of Allahabad. P. Asthana,

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed the revision petition of the appellant against the order of the Special Magistrate refusing to quash the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: order of the High Court of Allahabad dismissing the revision petition of the appellant against the order of the Special Magistrate refusing to quash the proceedings on the ground that the prosecution

facts.text: Prosecution of the appellant under sections 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code was claimed to be illegal without sanction under section 107 CrPC and section 6 of Prevention of Corruption Act II of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: the prosecution of the appellant inter alia under sections 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code was illegal and without jurisdiction in the absence of the sanction of the Government under section 107

facts.text: In 1947 the appellant held the office of Regional Deputy Iron and Steel Controller, Kanpur Circle, U.P., and was a public servant.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts are these. In 1947 the appellant held the office of Regional Deputy Iron and Steel Controller, Kanpur Circle, U.P., and was a public servant. The police having suspected the appella

facts.text: Police suspected the appellant to be guilty of offences under sections 161 and 165 IPC.

facts.text: On 22nd October 1947, police applied to Deputy Magistrate Kanpur for warrant of appellant's arrest.

anchor.surface_text: public servant. The police having suspected the appellant to be guilty of the offences mentioned above applied to the Deputy Magistrate, Kanpur, for a warrant of his arrest on the 22nd of October, 1947,

facts.text: Warrant of arrest was issued on 23rd October 1947.

anchor.surface_text: a warrant of his arrest on the 22nd of October, 1947, and the warrant was issued on the next day. The appellant was arrested on the 27th of October, 1947, but was granted bail.

facts.text: Police continued their investigation after 1st December 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Special Magistrate and was granted bail. The police continued their investigation. On the 6th of December, 1948, sanction was granted by the Provincial Government to prosecute the appellant

facts.text: On 6th December 1948, Provincial Government granted sanction to prosecute appellant under sections 161 and 165 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: their investigation. On the 6th of December, 1948, sanction was granted by the Provincial Government to prosecute the appellant inter alia under sections 161 and 165 of of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: On 31st January 1949, Central Government granted sanction in the same terms to prosecute appellant.

anchor.surface_text: under sections 161 and 165 of of the Indian Penal Code. On the 31st January, 1949, sanction in the same terms was granted by the Central Government. In the meantime as a result of an appeal

anchor.surface_text: by the Central Government. In the meantime as a result of an appeal made by the appellant to the High Court of Allahabad the amount of his bail was reduced and on the 25th of March, 1949,

facts.text: On 25th March 1949, appellant was ordered to be put up before the Magistrate to answer the charge-sheet submitted by prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: Allahabad the amount of his bail was reduced and on the 25th of March, 1949, the appellant was ordered to be put up before the Magistrate to answer the charge-sheet submitted by the prosecution.

facts.text: Decision went against appellant on sanction issue, he appealed to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore necessary to determine when the Magis- trate took cognizance of the offence. issues.text: the assumption that the Magistrate can issue a warrant only after taking cognizance of an offence under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code is unsound

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion having regard to the wording of section 3 of the Act the assumption that the Magistrate can issue a warrant only after taking cognizance of an offence under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code is unsound. The proviso to section 3 of the Act expressly covers the case of a Magistrate issuing a warrant for the arrest of a person in the course of investi- gation

arguments.claim: Cognizance of offence under s.190 CrPC taken upon receiving complaint, police report, or own information/suspicion

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore necessary to determine when the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence. The relevant part of section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code runs as follows-- 190. 1 Except as hereinafter provided, any Presidency Magistrate, District Magistrate or Sub-divisional Magistrate

arguments.claim: For cognizable offences, police can arrest without magistrate order during initial investigation stage

anchor.surface_text: It is important to remember that in respect of any cognizable offence, the police, at the initial stage when they are investigating the matter, can arrest a person without obtaining an order from the Magistrate. Under section 167 b of the Criminal Procedure Code the police have of course to put up the person so arrested before a Magistrate within 24 hours

arguments.claim: Offences u/s 161/165 IPC are non-cognizable under CrPC but deemed cognizable by s.3 Prevention of Corruption Act

anchor.surface_text: The offences for which the appellant is charged are under the Criminal Procedure Code non-cognizable and therefore if the matter fell to be determined only on the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code the appellant could not be arrested without an order of the Magistrate. The position however is materially altered because of section 3 of the Act

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.3 Act requires police below DSP to get magistrate order for investigation or arrest warrant during investigation

anchor.surface_text: Provided that a police officer below the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police shall not investigate any such offence without the order of a Magistrate of the first class or make any arrest therefor without a warrant.

arguments.claim: Magistrate order under proviso to s.3 is during police investigation, before completion and initiation under s.190 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The important point to be borne in mind is that the order of the Magistrate, which has to be obtained, is during the time the police is investigating the case and not when they have completed their investigation and are initiating the proceedings against the suspected person under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Assumption that Magistrate can issue warrant only after taking cognizance under s.190 is unsound; proviso to s.3 covers arrest warrant during investigation

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion having regard to the wording of section 3 of the Act the assumption that the Magistrate can issue a warrant only after taking cognizance of an offence under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code is unsound. The proviso to section 3 of the Act expressly covers the case of a Magistrate issuing a warrant for the arrest of a person in the course of investigation

arguments.claim: S.197 CrPC shows 'cognizance' indicates stage of initiation of proceedings; sections 190-199 grouped under 'Initiation of proceedings'

anchor.surface_text: The material part of section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code provides that where any public servant who is not removable from his office save with the sanction of Government is accused of an offence alleged to have been committed by him while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty, no court shall take cognizance of such offence except with the previous sanction

arguments.claim: Stage for warrant under proviso s.3 is not cognizance as contemplated by s.190 CrPC, s.197 CrPC, s.6 Act

anchor.surface_text: Reading sections 197 and 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6 of the Act in the light of the wording of the proviso to section 3, it is therefore clear that the stage at which a warrant is asked for under the proviso to section 3 of the Act is not on cognizance of the offence by the Magistrate as contemplated by the other three sections.

arguments.claim: Distinction of Emperor v. Sourindra Mohan Chuckerbutty: observations in context where magistrate expressly took cognizance

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant relied on some observations in Emperor v. Sourindra Mohan Chuckerbutty, in respect of the interpretation of the word cognizance. In that case... The observations taking cognizance does not involve any formal action... have to be read in the light of these facts.

arguments.claim: Cognizance indicated when magistrate first takes judicial notice for proceeding under Ch. XIV CrPC
Taking cognizance under s.190(1)(a) requires applying mind for purpose of proceeding under subsequent sections, not for ordering investigation u/s 156(3) or search warrant
In present case, Magistrate took cognizance only on 25th March 1949 when issuing notice under s.190 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, in the present case on the 25th March, 1949, the Magistrate issued a notice under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code against the appellant and made it returnable on the 2nd of May, 1949. That clearly shows that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence only on that day

arguments.claim: Sanction of the Central Government was void because it was not given by the Government of the State

anchor.surface_text: On the returnable date the appellant contended that the sanction of the Central Government was void because it was not given by the Government of the State.

holdings.text: The Magistrate took cognizance of the offence only on the 25th March, 1949 when he issued a notice under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, in the present case on the 25th March, 1949, the Magistrate issued a notice under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code against the appellant and made it returnable on the 2nd of May, 1949. That clearly shows that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence only on that day and acted under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice under s190 issued on that date evidences application of mind to initiate proceedings; prior warrant was during investigation.

holdings.text: Having regard to the wording of section 3 of the Act the assumption that the Magistrate can issue a warrant only after taking cognizance of an offence under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code is unsound.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion having regard to the wording of section 3 of the Act the assumption that the Magistrate can issue a warrant only after taking cognizance of an offence under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code is unsound. The proviso to section 3 of the Act expressly covers the case of a Magistrate issuing a warrant for the arrest of a person in the course of investi- gation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s3 expressly authorizes warrants during investigation of deemed cognizable offences, separate from s190 cognizance.

holdings.text: The order of the Magistrate which has to be obtained under proviso to section 3 is during the time the police is investigating the case and not when they have completed their investigation and are initiating the proceedings under section 190.

anchor.surface_text: The important point to be borne in mind is that the order of the Magistrate, which has to be obtained, is during the time the police is investigating the case and not when they have completed their investigation and are initiating the pro- ceedings against the suspected person under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme distinguishes police investigation phase requiring magistrate order for lower officers from post-investigation initiation of proceedings.

holdings.text: Reading sections 197 and 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6 of the Act in the light of the proviso to section 3, the stage at which a warrant is asked for under the proviso to section 3 is not cognizance of the offence as contemplated by those sections.

anchor.surface_text: Reading sections 197 and 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6 of the Act in the light of the wording of the proviso to section 3, it is therefore clear that the stage at which a warrant is asked for under the proviso to section 3 of the Act is not on cognizance of the offence by the Magistrate as contemplated by the other three sections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious interpretation aligns sanction requirements at initiation stage with proviso authorizing pre-cognizance warrants during probe.

holdings.text: Offences under sections 161 and 165 IPC are deemed cognizable under section 3 of the Prevention of Corruption Act notwithstanding CrPC provisions.

anchor.surface_text: The offences for which the appellant is charged are under the Criminal Procedure Code non-cognizable and therefore if the matter fell to be determined only on the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code the appellant could not be arrested without an order of the Magistrate. The position however is materially altered because of section 3 of the Act which runs as follows--

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s3 deeming provision overrides general CrPC classification for these corruption offences.

holdings.text: A Magistrate takes cognizance under section 190(1) when applying mind for purpose of proceeding under subsequent sections of Chapter XIV, not when ordering investigation under s156(3) or issuing search warrant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Approves precedent defining cognizance as judicial step towards process issuance, excluding pre-trial investigative aids.

holdings.text: Observations in Emperor v. Sourindra Mohan Chuckerbutty on cognizance must be read in light of facts where magistrate expressly took cognizance.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant relied on some observations in Emperor v. Sourindra Mohan Chuckerbutty, in respect of the interpretation of the word cognizance. In that case... The observations taking cognizance does not involve any formal action... have to be read in the light of these facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent as context-specific to express cognizance recording, not applicable to investigation warrants.

precedents.cited_proposition: what constitutes taking cognizance under section 190(1)(a) of the Criminal Procedure Code
precedents.cited_holding: before it can be said that any magistrate has taken companynizance of any offence under section 190 1 a , Criminal Procedure Code, he must number only have applied his mind to the companytents of the petition but he must have done so for the purpose of proceeding in a particular way [...] When the magistrate applies his mind number for the purpose of proceeding under the subsequent sections of this Chapter, but for taking action of some other kind, e.g., ordering investigation under section 156 3 , or issuing a search warrant for the purpose of the investiga- tion, he cannot be said to have taken companynizance of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, in the present case on the 25th March, 1949, the Magistrate issued a notice under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code against the appellant and made it returnable on the 2nd of May, 1949. That clearly shows that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence only on that day and acted under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion having regard to the wording of section 3 of the Act the assumption that the Magistrate can issue a warrant only after taking cognizance of an offence under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code is unsound. The proviso to section 3 of the Act expressly covers the case of a Magistrate issuing a warrant for the arrest of a person in the course of investi- gation
